Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Manufacturing of Nanostructure-Enhanced Mn-Al-base Materials via Modulated Machining and Thermomechanical Consolidation for High-Performance Permanent Magnets

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) award supports fundamental research on an innovative manufacturing process for the improved preparation of high performance permanent magnet materials. The process combines the preparation of high-purity micro-particulates that are internally composed of an ultrafine-grained structure from MnAl base alloys using a novel machining-based process. During subsequent low-temperature thermo-mechanical consolidation a composition-invariant solid-state phase transformation will be used to obtain dense bulk ferromagnetic aggregates. Magnetic and mechanical properties will be measured. Microstructure evolution during thermo-mechanical processing will be determined by x-ray diffraction and electron microscopy measurements. Physics based numerical models will be combined with experiments to determine the process-structure-property relationships. The research will provide the science underpinning the creation of the internally nanostructured alloy particulates, as well as for the phase transformation facilitated retention of the nano-scale grain size in the low-temperatue consolidated ferromagnetic aggregates.

The research provides new processing and materials science knowledge to meet the critical need for the effective manufacture of rare-earth-metal-free magnetic materials, which are critical to technologies used in the conversion between mechanical work and electrical power, as well as in transmission and distribution of power. Improved manufacture of permanent magnet materials based on abundant ingredients supports the implementation of clean wind power and electric vehicle technologies. Additionally, the underlying process schema is amenable for adaptation to a range of alloy systems. Therefore, the processing science knowledge the research will deliver is expected to advance the field of powder-particulate based manufacturing of functional and structural material in general. The research project involves an interdisciplinary academia-industry team from the University of Pittsburgh and Alcoa, provides synergy for project resources, ensures the industry relevance of the research, enables multifaceted graduate education for students, and expedites technology commercialization. It will also positively impact engineering education, promote lifelong learning for industrial practitioners, and broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) involved a research team from the University of Pittsburgh and Arconic (formerly Alcoa), Inc. The research studied the use of machining based orthogonal cutting operations for the preparation of Mn-Al alloy particulates that are suitable for the manufacture of permanent magnet (PM) materials based on ferromagnetic tau-MnAl with nano-feature enhanced performance.  Vacuum induction melting and heat-treatments have been used to prepare Mn-Al alloy materials with controlled composition in the range of 53.5 atomic % ≤ Mn ≤ 54.5 atomic %.  These served as bulk feedstock for machining-based preparation of paramagnetic epsilon-phase Mn-Al particulates. Using end-milling as the selected example orthogonal cutting operation with manual and computer-numerically-controlled machining platforms, a range of process-dependent conditions have been determined that effectively impart severe plastic deformation and create Mn-Al alloy particulates with nano-scale refined internal structure. Low-temperature (T≤700K) thermal and thermo-mechanical treatments have been used to transform the severely plastically deformed paramagnetic alloy particulates prepared by the machining processes via composition-invariant phase transformation into a nanostructured hard ferromagnetic material comprised predominantly of tau-phase MnAl. Combinations of thermal and magnetic property measurements by differential scanning calorimetry and vibrating sample magnetometry have been used in conjunction with structural analyses and micro-characterization by X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy to determine the associated processing-structure-property relationships.

The effort has demonstrated that machining-based approaches are suitable for preparation of rare-earth-element-free ferromagnetic Mn-Al alloys with PM material performance characteristics that are competitive with those attained via other approaches, e.g. those involving ball-milling. The research provides a foundation for potential future activities to develop automated or robotic CNC based preparation technology for high-throughput particulate preparation that could facilitate further enhanced performance of hard ferromagnetic tau-phase MnAl alloys. Machining technology therefore holds potential for development of practical methods for the controlled, facile manufacture of functional nanomaterials in particulate form. The fundamental knowledge base generated here regarding the evolution of nanostructures obtained by the high-strain-rate severe plastic deformation of machining processes in response to thermal and thermo-mechanical processing enables broadening to other materials. This research added to the basic and applied materials science knowledge base and enhanced the prospects of wider utilization of high-performance nanostructured alloys in energy, transportation, defense and biomedical technologies.

Research results been emanated to the public via presentations, integrated into educational activities related to manufacturing and product realization in the industrial and the materials science and engineering curricula at the University of Pittsburgh. A graduate student received research training in physical metallurgy, phase transformations, permanent magnet materials, microstructure characterization with X-ray and electron beams, and also in manufacturing science and technology development and innovation. The collaboration with the GOALI partner provided professional preparation outside of the academic environment for a future member of the US science, technology and engineering workforce.

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2018
Modified by: Jorg M Wiezorek

The research studied the use of machining based orthogonal cutting operations for the preparation of Mn-Al alloy particulates that are suitable for the manufacture of permanent magnet (PM) materials based on ferromagnetic tau-MnAl with nano-feature enhanced performance.
